description: Goopy white wine, made of the Mycus fruit.
A viscous, soft pink wine, made from the fruit of the Marloss.
Sparkling white wine, made from the world's noblest grape.
//: Booze uses nonstandard charge counts: 15 shots of wine to the 750mL bottle.  Priced at 1100 translates to $33 per, because it's still priced per 250 mL charge.

description: America's most popular wine, and for good reason.
//: The PLCB can get you some for around $10 per 750mL, but I imagine you want to pay for better ~fermentation~.

description: The heavily disputed king of red wines.  Pairs well with red meats and pasta.
Prized by collectors and adored by critics, this is one of the rarer and more elegant wines.
A wine popularly used in dishes served in Italian restaurants.
A soft wine with a pleasant herbal flavor and aroma.  It is a common cocktail ingredient, and can be used as a substitute for white wine.
Despite the name, this is technically a strong beer and not wine, but there's no need to be pedantic about it.
A distilled grain alcohol, made from, by, and for real Southern colonels!
//: Given the comment, presuming we're taking bourbon here.

description: A beverage of alcohol, water, and not much else.  In America, men make vodka, but in Soviet Russia, vodka makes the man.
An alcoholic beverage flavored with juniper berries.  It smells faintly of berries, but mostly booze.
A distilled alcoholic beverage made from fermenting molasses.  Drinking it might make you feel like a pirate.  Or not.
A distilled alcoholic beverage made from a succulent plant with spiky leaves.  Don't eat the worm!  Wait, there's no worm in this bottle.
An orange-flavored liquor used in many mixed drinks.
A Japanese alcoholic beverage made by fermenting rice with the use of yeast and koji mold.  This one is mostly clear, as it has been filtered.
A Japanese alcoholic beverage made by fermenting rice with the use of yeast and koji mold.  This one has a cloudy white color because of fine rice particles in it, as it has not been filtered.
Really cheap fortified wine.
Strong alcoholic drinks, mixed with no regard for taste.
Weak alcoholic drinks, mixed with no regard for taste.
Cheap booze made from fermented fruit juice.  Tastes as good as it sounds.
Wine that has been distilled to a higher proof.  Great as an after-dinner drink, but packs a punch.
A cocktail made by mixing beer and grenadine syrup.  It's quite sweet.
Sweetened coffee and whiskey topped with milk.  Start your day the closeted alcoholic way!
A cocktail made by mixing coffee and pure alcohol, typically moonshine, originating from Scandinavia.  Sometimes sugar is also added.
A cocktail made by mixing black tea and rum, which has its origins in the British Army.
A blend of incredibly strong-flavored liquors that somehow tastes like none of them.  It contains no tea, but the inclusion of cola gives it a tea-like color.
//: Includes cola, so presumed to be a 250mL cocktail like the others.

description: A mix of orange juice and vodka.  It's the surreptitious drunkard mechanic's drink of choice.  A similar drink may be made by substituting cranberry juice for orange juice.
Like apple cider, only with vodka.
Suitable for tropical retreats and Canadian artists alike.  In certain variants, whiskey or sake is substituted for rum.

A mixed alcoholic drink consisting of gin and tonic water, created in the 19th century as a way to make tonic water (a malaria prophylactic) more palatable, but still popular to this day.  In certain variants, vodka is substituted for gin.
A cocktail consisting of pineapple juice, coconut milk, and rum, originating in Puerto Rico.  In certain variants, vodka, whiskey, or tequila are substituted for rum.

A cocktail consisting of tequila, orange juice, and grenadine syrup, originating from California.  In certain variants, vodka or rum may be substituted for tequila, and pineapple juice may be substituted for orange juice.
A generic-brand grain alcohol flavored with hops.  It's best served cold, in a glass, and with a lime - but you're not that lucky.
Well-aged honey wine, spiced with a hint of hops.  Goes down bittersweet.
Homebrewed honey wine, spiced with a bit of hops.  Goes down bittersweet.
Homebrewed honey wine, a smooth and silky golden beverage.
Homebrewed spiced honey wine, a tasty beverage that can be served hot or cold.
A light and delicious wine made from dandelion flowers.  Slightly effervescent, it is smooth and crisp.
//: Nope, homebrew is not more expensive than pinot noir, sorry.

description: A light and delicious wine made from burdock roots.  Somewhat sweet.
A potent wine flavored with pine resin.  Bold and pungent, its biting taste and strong aroma takes some getting used to.
Not the finest drink you've had, but hey, it's alcohol by the gallon.
Only the strongest, purest, good ol' fashioned hooch, distilled from corn (or pumpkin) and sugar.  Guaranteed to make you forget about the whole Cataclysm thing, or you get your vision back.
A lager beer imported from Europe.  Best served cold, in a glass - but you're not that lucky.
A tasty domestic craft beer.  Best served cold, in a glass - but you're not that lucky.
A very flavorful microbrewed beer.  Best served cold, in a glass - but you're not that lucky.
A tasty craft beer, as dark in color as the days ahead.
A flavorful and filling beer brewed by monks in Belgium.  Best served in a goblet.

A very flavorful beer that has been aged in bourbon barrels.  It is as black as midnight on a moonless night and has the viscosity of oil.  While very tasty, it also has an alcohol content on par with wine.
Strawberries left to ferment with a few other choice ingredients offer up a surprisingly palatable mixture; you barely even have to force yourself to drink it after the first few gulps.
This fermented blueberry mixture is surprisingly hearty, though the soup-like consistency is slightly unsettling no matter how much you drink.
Only the finest whiskey straight from the bung.
//: Priced by the 100 liter barrel, this is multiplied by 400 to achieve the final cost.

description: A whiskey made from a mixed mash of malted and unmalted barley.
Really cheap blended whiskey.
A multi-grain liquor made from a mash of corn and rye.
East India Solera.  A true drink of a British gentleman.  Sherry, Niles?
A fine sherry that has been aged in American oak casks and bottled in Bristol, England.
Fortified wine from Madeira.  A true Royal Navy drink.
This definitely tastes like a hobo drink.
A mix of equal parts wine and cola, originating in Spain in the 1920s.  Tastes better than it sounds.
This cocktail dates from the Prohibition era.  Gin, honey and lemon in a delightful mix.
A mixed drink made of whiskey and lemon juice, with sugar added.  In certain variants, gin is substituted for whiskey.
A mixed drink combining bee and ant honey.  It tastes great, and it's a good source of nourishment.

Droplet-shaped ant food.  It's like a thick balloon the size of a baseball, filled with sticky liquid.  Unlike bee honey, this has mostly a sour taste, probably because ants feed upon a variety of things.
Smooth and rich, this spoon-coating mixture of milk, cream, eggs, and booze is a popular traditional holiday drink.  Having been fortified with alcohol, it will keep for a long time.
//: A 12-charge gallon currently goes for around US$4, and eggnog is a bit more expensive than that.

description: A popular cocktail made with gin and dry vermouth, dating from the Prohibition era.  In certain variants, vodka or tequila is substituted for gin.
Tomato juice mixed with vodka and some spices.  A hangover cure of choice for many.
This is definitely not tomato juice.
Alcoholic sparkling water infused with delicious fruit.  Perfect for a hot summer day.
Alcoholic sparkling water infused with delicious fruit.  Perfect for a hot summer day.  Tastes nearly as good as the one in the market.
